item.title: Moedermelk delen
item.dc:creator: Erik van Zummeren
item.content:encoded:
Together with Marit Willemsen and Tove Oegema, I worked on a story about mothermilk sharing through social media in the Netherlands. We did the research during the final stage of our master studies and which we later on sold to Nieuwsuur.

The accompanying news article can be found on the website of the NOS.

item.title: The White Cube Website
item.dc:creator: Erik van Zummeren
item.content:encoded:
Did the design, development, and a small part of the PR of the launch of the Lusanga International Research Centre for Art and Economic Inequality. The launch got picked up by a wide variety of media such as VICE, ARTnews, HarpersBazaarArabia, Inquirer and even Breitbart.

Made during my time at Pieter van Huystee.

item.title: De pont van kwart over zeven
item.description: 'Erger is dat de politicus die het woord voert niet begrijpt dat hij hún taal allang niet meer verstaat.' Met deze woorden eindigde Gerard van Westerloo in 1981 zijn reportage De pont van kwart over zeven, over een groep pontvaarders op de Buiksloterveer in Amsterdam. Voelt de pontvaarder zich
item.dc:creator: Erik van Zummeren
item.content:encoded:
'Erger is dat de politicus die het woord voert niet begrijpt dat hij hún taal allang niet meer verstaat.' Met deze woorden eindigde Gerard van Westerloo in 1981 zijn reportage De pont van kwart over zeven, over een groep pontvaarders op de Buiksloterveer in Amsterdam. Voelt de pontvaarder zich bijna veertig jaar later nog steeds zo onbegrepen?

Gemaakt met Marit Willemsen en Floor Bouma.

Of klik hier voor een live-versie.

item.title: Historical Dutch Asiatic Trading
item.description:
Historical Dutch-Asiatic Trading (HDAT) shows an interpolation of the historical Dutch-Asiatic and Intra-Asiatic trading lines. The data visualisation, which I made with RJ Korteschiel, shows the overall size of the trade. With the help of minard lines the trading size of individual goods are also shown.

The underlying data is
item.dc:creator: Erik van Zummeren
item.content:encoded:
Historical Dutch-Asiatic Trading (HDAT) shows an interpolation of the historical Dutch-Asiatic and Intra-Asiatic trading lines. The data visualisation, which I made with RJ Korteschiel, shows the overall size of the trade. With the help of minard lines the trading size of individual goods are also shown.

The underlying data is based on the Boekhouders-Generaal Batavia (BGB) database, a database that was digitized and provided by the Huygens ING. The BGB contains data on the departure or arrival of around 20 000 ships in the 18th century, and the inventory of these ships.

A network, based on the atlas Van Keulen and various shipping logs, was drawn in QGIS. Through PgRouting and PostGIS these routes were connected with the ships. The sailing speeds were interpolated with the help of the data from the daily shipping logs.

Frontend was done in Leaflet and React.

Later on I used the database and the visualisation as the base for my bachelor thesis on the Dutch trade with Persia.
